reviewText:
Considerations of this game from most important to least:
-It's free to play (truly)
-it remains about as faithful to true Lord of the Rings lore as any game has ever done so far
-bonuses that are available to players who pay premium can be acquired by free-to-play players by doing a nominal amount of grinding (and if you want to get the expansions for free, you can grind a hell of a lot and still manage to get those as well)
-game is entirely playable as a single player if you so desire (offering power ups at key story points if you don't have a group)
-a very friendly community of players that is extremely helpful

Honestly, the only downside that I see to this game is that once you reach roughly level 30 (which does not take a ton of time - I reached level 20 after a few days of playing) things start to take a lot more time.  This is because a lot of the features in the game, such as fast-travel, mile-stone bindpoints (teleportation points), and upgraded mounts aren't available immediately to free-to-play players.  That is not to say that mounts are entirely unavailable to free-to-play players however, a mount is available to any character at roughly level 20.  Obviously it is necessary for the company to provide services that must be paid for in order to keep the game running, and considering the fact that an entirely new player could go into the game and immediately start playing what would be roughly 70% of the game content without spending a penny; that is a pretty good deal.  Not to mention that, as i said previously, if you grind 'turbine points' in game enough, you can collect enough to pay for all of the expansions - granted it would take a long time, but it is certainly possible.

All in all, i would rate this game 9/10.  The point loss is purely because there are still a few extremely minor inaccuracies in the game that are noticeable to Lord of the Rings fans who are extremely knowledgeable to the lore.

reviewText:
I've been playing this game since it became free to play, and I feel like every update since has been making the game better and better for me. I'm a big fan of Middle Earth and getting to see bits of lore that you don't experience in film (like Tom Bombadil for instance) really helps bring this world to life. I love the emphasis on kindness and friendship, and following the epic storyline makes you feel like you are a part of this world and that you all matter.

As far as gameplay goes, I feel it is fairly standard in terms of controls - easy to get the hang of once you learn the differences from other games. Some people may not agree with the locking out of certain features in-game for free players, but these are easily unlockable with enough effort and determination without having to spend a penny. I personally did end up subscribing for a few months to unlock a lot of content. Since then, I am always considered a premium account and I keept a lot of the features that were unlocked with subscribing.

This is my favorite free to play MMORPG out there at this time.

reviewText:
First of all i want to point out that im a f2p user on this MMO, and i have by-passed many restrictions without a problem. Its an absoloutely amazing game, especially if you're a big fan of the LOTR triology, as you can easily relate to many parts in this game, story, characters etc etc...The game truly has great content, and a huge world to explore as you level up to capin at 105 :) ...Graphics are quite decent , especially on high specs, and runs quite well on alot of systems.. no matter if you have an average pc/laptop etc...Communities are great and there is always someone there to give you a helping hand when you start off. Apart from the exciting and adventurous story and quests, LOTRO also brings PVP, which is quite competitive involving the Freeps( the good side :) ) vs Creeps( the monsters/bad side). Both are playable and both are great, its all up to a matter of preference which side you would like to PVP as :) I wont review that in detail, but there's plenty of playthroughs and info on pvp online.

Im currently a lvl 52 Beorning [ with a lvl 63 hunter : Dirar ] ( totally F2p ) in the server of Evernight, Name : Hranvir, and have not spent a single cent getting here, with an expansion, and around 3 quest packs, as well as gold cap, Auction house slots,beorning class w/ character slot , and  more restrictions all unlocked by doing the deeds, quests etc to unlock these ( Turbine points/ TP ) , basically farming and also using different alt characters to repeat... making hundreds each run. It just shows that if you're a F2p even for the start, how far and how much you can achieve without paying anything, just with some time,patience and dedication, which will pay off in the end :) . Its up to you if you want to pay for the end game expansions, content etc something that i might possibly consider, (even going VIP for 1 month will unlock many permanent restrictions on your account, aswell as giving you some TP, only for the price of $15 I think) I have not done it yet but its definitely worth it imho.

Overall, if you loved the LOTR story/books, and are a huge fan of MMO's ,you like open world action, the freedom to do/go as you wish, meet many new friends, and encounter some great adventures... this is the game for you! :)
I personally love this game and once you get started, its quite tricky to let go :) its just really exciting, and is a great experience to try out.. and i would certainly recommend this to anyone and you should download and give it a go right away! ^^ If you would like to have a deeper look into the game/gameplay/action and so forth, Youtube is simply the way, as it will show you through gameplay, the races/classes/mounts/ etc etc. so do check that out!

LOTRO is definitely a great MMO, and one you will certainly get to grips with and enjoy! :)

reviewText:
I've been playing LOTRO for 8 years and have a lifetime subscription (which is no longer available to purchase).

If you love Tolkien's Middle-earth, you'll enjoy visiting Turbine's interpretation of it in LOTRO.
If you enjoy theme park-style MMORPGs and don't mind playing an older title, you'll probably like LOTRO, too.
If you're looking for PvP, you'll find it's limited in LOTRO, but still has a lot of passionate players.
If you only enjoy competitive max-level raiding for world firsts
date: LOTRO probably isn't for you.\nIf you like making music or role-playing, LOTRO will probably be like heaven.\nI really can't think of a reason for anyone not to give LOTRO a try. Even if it doesn't have all the features you're looking for, you might still fall in love with the setting, the story, or the community.

reviewText: Before the Rider's of Rohan expansion, especially around the time of Mines of Moria expansion, this was easily the best MMO on the market. reviewText:
Great game if you are into slow paced games. With its beautiful sceneries and amazing music, you get this lotr feeling when you play it. Recommended if you are willing to spend money after you have advanced a little in the game (you have seen nothing when you have reached level 20, so much left to do!)

cons:
Very demanding in terms of in-game avaiability, you have to purchase off restrictions, like gold cap.
You can't proceed further than level 30 if you are not interested in grinding repeated in-game activites.
Not much player activity in old game areas, whereas at the level cap there is tons of player activity(depending on which server)

pros:
Beautiful and large sceneries, you can travel from thorin's hall to east-Rohan!
You have to dedicate your time if you want to reach the best of the best, making it kind of adictive.
Many recreations from Tolkiens books!
Possible to earn enough in-game currency to unlock anything you want which would cost money, if you have time.


8/10

reviewText:
If you are going to play it, purely F2P, you can, by grinding TP ( Turbine Points ).
You can basically get the whole game that way, at the cost of several months of straight-up farming/grinding.

I highly recommend that you play with other people, whether you know them or not. Playing solo is boring, as it is slow. Some classes can actually make soloing easy. However, playing solo is entirely viable. At the moment, any class can mow down tons of enemies on their own. At levels 1-90, you will hardly find anyone to play with, there isn't enough people to do stuff with, or they don't have the content, as they have to buy it.

There's also a bunch of classes with their own mechanics, the most basic of them being the Guardian.

If you like LOTR lore, this is for you, however, don't expect amazing end-game stuff, and don't expect a top-of-the-line story.
Some may enjoy the story of LOTRO, as it ties you with the main characters from LOTR, but some may also be bored with the main stuff, rather quickly.

The PVP is...meh. There isn't any structured PVP so it's all in a region called the Ettenmoors. The balance is for PVP has always been bad/awful, as there is always something OP.

The community is fairly helpful compared to many other games, but there is always an occasionally jerk/idiot/whatever.

If you come expecting amazing, you'll kinda feel let down. But it's good enough to say the least.                                                                 Try the game, see if you like it. It's free.

reviewText:
Although this game seems outdated and there are a few problems with it, I love it.

Some of the strong points of the game include:
Story and lore - there is a ton of story and lore packed into this game, which is awesome if you're a Tolkien fan
Music - the music is top-notch for the most part and really fits the world well
PvE content - there is always something to do, whether it's following a quest chain to level up you or your epic weapon, following the main storyline, fighting in a skirmish, decortaing your personal or kin house, or participating in one of the many festivals
Character housing - something WoW has yet to implement...
Some of the weak points of the game are:
Rewards - Turbine has a problem with giving away proper rewards in their games. It happens in their D&D game as well. you can run through a long Instance for 20 minutes and get a bit of skirmish marks, or you can do a quick skirmish and get the same number of skirmish marks. And the daily gifts are usually something you don't need or want
PvP is lacking - I'm not very much into PvP, but if you are, this probably isn't the game for you. The PvP (in LoTRO, PvMP) system seems stale and boring. It is cool to be able to fight on the monster side, though
Graphics are outdated - models and animations need to be updated, though there are many times the graphics are quite beautiful. I appreciate that the graphics are less cartoony than other MMO's, but an update would help a lot

Many people complain about it now being F2P, but it doesn't bother me, I just love the LoTR world and love being part of it. This game may not be everyone's cup of tea, but I definitely recommend it for a shade of Earl Grey.

reviewText:
While it is fun to play as a dwarven minstrel in Middle Earth the game is created by Turbine, unfortunately that comes with the complications that it's 100% pay to win, 100% locked content unless you either subscribe or buy the stuff, and 100% grindy in an attempt to get you to spend money on the cash shop.

The end-game you're supposed to look forward to at level 95 is locked for non-monsters unles you're a VIP. It's called Monster Play and has had very little done in terms of making it even remotely balanced. They never have been very bright about this kinda thing though (Turbine tends to think PvE can completely carry an MMO).

If you're a hardcore lord of the rings fan or you have a lot of patience for grinding slayer achievements for turbine points then I can recommend this game to you. Otherwise I can't recommend except for a casual approach.

To see a full and somewhat less irate review, check the link below:

http://uncrownedreview.blogspot.com/2015/02/the-lord-of-rings-online.html

reviewText:
Yes the game is old, but so are the books that the game's based on.
The lore is there, and the areas are there, almost as good as the books. The main story (epic quests) has you following the fellowship (or running parallel), working in the background to fight the rising evil, aiding the good cause.
You will quest around landmarks from the books like Weathertop, and you can find little touches like the petrified trolls in the Trollshaws.

It may not have the best graphics (but certainly not the worst either). I grew up with a Commodore 64, so gameplay is more important than graphics for me, but things like the use of lighting to set the mood works really well for me, as does the weather.

It is F2P, but that doesn't mean it doesn't cost a thing to have all content available.
The good thing is that the store credits (Turbine Points) can be earned in-game, and that you can buy almost everything that is included in the VIP status with it. The only notable exception is 'fast travel' which you really will miss if you haven't got it, as the game is BIG.
The bad thing is that earning TP quickly is a grind, although it can be sped up if you have some high level characters.

Combat is old school skill clicking, which you either like or dislike.
Crafting is extremely simple; you have the mats, you make the item. (with a % to critical success). I would have liked something more involving, like EverQuest II's crafting perhaps.
Crafting does require interaction with other players, as you won't be able to get all materials you need yourself for the crafts you choose.

If you are into PvP, then this game is not for you.
There is some sort of PvP (PvMP), where some players have a character on the evil side, and some players play their regular 'good' side characters. There's one map for it, and the PvP crowd varies wildly per server.

If you are into endgame raids, then this game is not for you. There is no (new) endgame content. There are scaling instances, which are essentially the same from L20 upwards, except with harder enemies.
There is some new endgame content in the making though.

Most of the population is helpful and mature, but, as this is an online game, there are some trolls and trouble makers on the chat channels. Although vocal, this is a very small group compared to the helpful people.

Oh, one major bad thing: The download is HUGE, and the update process is extremely slow compared to other MMOs.

Overall: If you like the Lord of the Rings lore (whether from the books or the movies) and like to explore Middle Earth yourself, then this is the only game to play.
It's free up to around L30, after which you need to unlock quests for other areas.
Whether you pay for it with money or with time is up to you, which is a fair deal IMO.

And remember, the journey is more important than the goal.

reviewText:
Any fan of Lord of the Rings--casual or otherwise--will enjoy this game immensely. Every server is still highly populated (although some areas may seem barren because really, who wants to spend all day in an area that has litterally one building for miles?) and filled with people of all ages. I've met high school freshman and college graduates. The people playing this game are extremely nice and mature. I've only had two encounters with genuinely mean people and I never had to deal with them alone even if I was playing alone.

There are lots of quests to do solo and lots to do in groups as little as 2 and as big as 8. There's also a mode where more than one fellowship can play together or somehing I'm pretty sure but I have yet to hit the appropriate level so I can't confirm. If none of your friends wan to play with you worry not! Most everyone is approachable and everyone has common ground. Unlike WoW or GW2 where you could start playing not knowing if you'll ever care about the lore, everyone on LOTRO likes LOTR. Some prefer the books, others prefer the movies, but you all have that common ground.

There are RP servers but if you don't only want to roleplay, there are an abdundance of roleplayers running around on the normal servers to satisfy your urges when you get them.

Gameplay itself is also fun. I wouldn't say it's the most outstanding thing in the entire world. You'll find similar mechanics in other MMOs and it's not any more or less engaging than those other MMOs. Depending on your class you'll get to see some really cool animations, though.

The main storyline is also very engaging and very fun for fans of LOTR. I remember obsessing over it when I first started playing, haha.

So yeah 10/10 I do recommend.

reviewText: What can I say that hasn't already been said about Lord of the Rings Online. Released in 2007, this game has captured my attention since it was first launched with the title Shadows of Angmar. One of the last true RPGs found within the MMO genre, the game captivates with its art and design that still manages to impress nearly a decade later. Despite drawbacks in population, ownership change at Turbine (purchased by Warner Bros in 2010), and the launch of A Free-2-Play model shortly after, LOTRO still has a magical draw about it that compels players to take up arms against the Dark Lord and trek across Middle-Earth. The game is worth the subscription cost, especially if purchased for 3 or more months in advance. If unable to afford the fee, there is a Free option with limitations; just about all of which can be unlocked in-game through the use of Turbine Points gained from completing various Deeds, both kill, quest and reputation. In general, the community is helpful- much of the time willing to assist a newcomer with answers to their many questions. Give the game a try, it is perfect for the hardcore quester, casual gamer, role-player and explorer; something for just about everyone.

reviewText:
A long-enduring ever-expansive homage to the alternative history that is Middle-Earth, that will absolutely bury you in its many miniature gameplay mechanics steadily accumulated and tweaked over its now 8-year-long course.  And while it my look like an overwhelming ammount of content to go through to a new player, the fact that this game is most proud of is, be you a level 1, 30, 50 or 100, there always seems plenty to do to feel rewarding, and a time well spent.


Mechanically, its a by-the-numbers MMORPG game, very much entrenched into evey known trope of an early 21st century online game. But its style and gameplay hasn't yet been hampered by it, rather built around it. There's the standard 50+ skillbar of each fairly ballanced class which compliment eachother in a D&D kind of way (the tanky one, the squishy dps one, the buffer, the healer, the run-around-do-whatever-you-like one), working together without ironic subtext, since Tolkien basically wrote the book on them  (ugh...) inadvertently defined the classical dungeon crawling class system anyway. You TAB around the monsters presented and diminish their red bars. Alternatively, you gather materials, craft, randomly explore, complete numerous deeds, roleplay (it is, obviously, an extremely RP frienldy game), buy junk, sell junk, play through story mode, pvmp, do instances (scalable) do quests, do quests, do quests........

The strongest parts are indeed the stories of numerouns inhabitants of the world, gated behind and propelled by your typical fetch and kill x quests. You could do a lot worse then reading through abysmal ammount of text walls of these chatty NPC's, and, if you're a fan of the setting, it will be a treat throughout the game. It is skippable of course, but this is a text heavy game.

The FTP model can safely get you through 1-50 without much hassle, and the remaining content is gated behind purchases, but, by then, you'll already decide if its worth your money and time. As stated above, there's plenty to do in Eriador anyway, before venturing forth through Moria into Rhovanion, Rohan and Gondor.

Tip: Get a mount as soon as you can, it's a massive game. And don't venture into Prancing Pony drunk.

Oh yeah, grinding is, for the most part, optional.

Highly reccomended.

reviewText:
Though it's old this is a very beautiful game. And it is very true to Tolkien's world of middle earth. So as a Tolkien fan I would recommend this game just for the world alone. I will never forget the first time I saw Weathertop or entered the mines of Moria.

The quests have a feel of old MMOs. They can be rather grindy at times. But the main (epic) quest line is very well written and pulls you into the game. The community in the game is very nice and helpful. I don't know if it's because I play on a RP server, but I have never been trolled or anything for asking a question on world chat. But asking in chat you never have to wait long to find someone willing to sell what you're looking for.

reviewText:
This is definitely my favourite MMO that I have played to date. I have played it before getting Steam, so I have way more game time than it actually shows.

This game is basically WOW, except less limited in the free to play.
You can unlock everything in the game just in F2P, and there is no difference, except for a few perks, between a player who is F2P or not. There is one location that requires you to be VIP : a location for Player vs Monster Player fighting, but there is another location for that.

The graphics are not disappointing, considering this game was initially released in 2009, but could use an upgrade to bring them to modern level.

Speaking of updates, these are happening constantly, with bug fixes, but also new areas and locations, quests, and other content.

Now for the quests. Well, to be completely honest with you, while the main epic quest is loads of fun, and actually had me engrossed in the story for quite some time, (It's really good !), the intro quest for the Elf start is.... lacking.

Sure the beginning of it is, kind of awesome, in the middle it is just pure boredom. I had to spend several different day doing it, simply because I was bored with the walking - talking - walking - fetch item - walking quests. That would literally be nearly half of the quests in the tutorial, which takes an HOUR to complete. That being said, the end of the Elf tutorial picks up the pace once again, but - not really that great.

Combat is absolutely fine, no issues with the abilities of any kind, Hunters' focus system is to be enjoyed with the balance. Different combinations of the abilities can be used to fight different monsters and also people. There is a PvP system - you can spar outside of major cities.

The map is just spectacular. You can explore the entirety of Middle-Earth, with different regions corresponding to different skill levels so you always have something to do in the game.


Overall - 8/10, really fun game, but a few of the quests are boring and repetitive, with a few bugs.

reviewText:
I have been playing LotRO for over 10 years and have followed it since it was called Middle Earth Online. This is the ONE MMORPG that I continually play. Why? Because it is so engaging. JRR Tolkien's world comes alive as you visit those most famous of places in any fantasy setting. Rivendell, the Shire, the Misty Mountains, Moria, Lothlorien, Mirkwood, Isengard, Rohan and Helms Deep, Gondor, and soon setting foot on the threshhold of the Dark Lord himself; the Black Gate, and Mordor!

There's so much more to explore. Turbine has done a wonderful job creating so much content that is in the Middle Earth lore and your character is engaged in many different stories on their way to assist the Fellowship of the Ring in their ultimate quest; to destroy the One Ring!

Gameplay is average for an MMO, but I find with the different classes and especially as you level, your character becomes more powerful; no matter which class you play!

There's so much more to the game than just PvE and questing. You can craft until your heart's content. Decorate your home, kinship home, or entire neighborhood of kinfolk. Legendary Items and armour definitely set your character on the path to greatness!

Mounted combat and collecting so many different types of mounts and steeds is pretty fun. Along with the numerous year-round festivals that occur. It allows you to continue to do something new all the time. If you get bored with raiding and questing, go take down some Roving Threats with your friends, hunt for lost treasure, and even engage in some rather fun PvP raids in the Ettenmoors. PvMP as it is called in LotRO is fun; either solo, small fellowship, full fellowship, or join in on a raid to take down some powerful enemy fortresses! There are also associated quests and rewards for gaining ranks in PvMP.

So, overall, I would give LotRO a 8.5/10. The -1.5 would be for a bit dated game engine and graphics, but it is definitely a lot better than same-aged MMOs and older for sure! (WoW, EQ, EQ2, etc.) Also, it lacks a bit of visual panache that some of the current movies and games offer. The gear artwork is a bit too middle ages European style (clothing, gear, etc.) for my liking. I rather like some of the cosmetic outfits style far better than the actual gear that you get as armour, clothing, etc. They feel far more like what you might see in the Lord of the Rings / Hobbit movies. Much more realistic imho.

So there's my review. I hope it gives you a feel for the game and that you will come and try it out. Just stick with it! Grind past in to your 70s and you will definitely see what I mean! Stick with LotRO and you will be rewarded and see why I've stayed with it these many years!

Regards!

reviewText: All the reviews below pretty much sum up how I feel about Lord of the Rings Online. I just felt the need to mention one feature that no one else mentioned, and that I feel makes LOTRO unique like no other MMO- the player music system. You can equip a musical instrument in game and, either by hitting keys or launching an ABC music file, play a song in game that people in the area can hear. Players have formed bands that give concerts, and on Landroval server there is even a yearly event called Weatherstock that attracts musicians from many servers for a day of music on Weathertop. Even if you don't roleplay, the abilty to perform and listen to player music in game adds so much to the experience.

reviewText: If you're looking for a world where the soul is in the heartfelt community rather than flash-in-the-pan, technological gimmicks, look no further than this version of Middle Earth. Come, explore, make some friends, relax, and be fulfilled by the best kind of 'leveling' & 'progress', the kind that involves no stats nor scores. The kind that involves spending the whole day fishing and talking with friends, perhaps serenading a random audience in the town square with a song that you literally wrote, or having a snowball fight in Winter, or even racing through a corn maze in Fall. Sure you could get to max level if you want, but this is a world where the person with the best attitude wins, not the one with the highest level, thanks to the best MMORPG community I've ever seen.

reviewText:
If you're a RolePlayer this is almost a must-try MMORPG. LotRo has one of the best RP communities on it's Landroval server that you will find pretty much anywhere. Fairly standard combat for an MMO, but the Rohan expansion adds quite a bit of flare to that. You won't find better in terms of lore, immersion, and a die hard tolkein fan base.

The game's one downfall in my opinion is the free-to-play model that is currently in place. You will be spending a lot of time re-rolling characters and running the same zones over and over to earn enough points to unlock the next quest packs, expansions, bag upgrades etc.. etc.. My recommendation is to subscribe and get everything for a monthly fee, minus the expansions that will have to be purchased of course.

reviewText:
I, unfortunately, can not recommend LOTRO.  I really want to, but can't.
It's lots of fun, don't get me wrong, especially when played with a few friends.  But the hamhanded attempts to wring money out of the game by Turbine will be kicking the back of your seat the whole way.
Look, I understand that a Free to Play game still has to make some money for upkeep costs and whatnot, but NOT BEING ABLE TO REACH THE ORIGINAL LEVEL CAP FROM 7 YEARS AGO IS A SLAP IN THE FACE.
If you end up playing you will find out you can reach level 35-40, depending on how much grind you do.  The original level cap was 50.
Again, I'm not saying that they should give away the expansions, thats what makes all the long term money, but not letting players reach the original base level cap, and without telling them in advance, is honestly a terrible thing to do.
It has has left a bad taste in my mouth that will likely be my last inpression of this once fun game.

I guess if I had to sum this up it would be...
Fun, but don't let the Free to Play" tagline fool you.  In order to play more than 1/3rd of the game you have to sink close to 70 bucks into it for expansion and quest packs."

reviewText: This was one of my first MMOs and I am so happy it was. The combat and graphics may seem a little outdated but it is still fun beyond belief. It's not easy but it's not too challenging, it's super fun to play with your friends, the map is GIANT and there's so much to see and do. Within my first few days of playing I was invited to a guild by very nice players who taught me everything and showed me how to play, I progressed slowly until I was a total bad ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, I spent hours looking for the correct ores to make the best weapons and armor possible. The gameplay is perfect. You start out by fighting wolves with a weak short sword and leather armor and a few days later you'll be taking on orcs and giants with your friends and dual wielding swords that took hours to make and heavy steel armor. THe progression is quite slow which personally I love. But that may bother some people. You can do epic boss fights and raids to earn special money that you can spend at camps to get weapons and armor that look like they were crafted by the gods. This game is also truly free to play. If you want to spend real money on special coins go ahead but it's definitely not forced upon you. You can do everything without spending a dime. I played this game all spring break with my friend. It doesn't matter if you have an old mac and a poor mouse. I spent the majority of this game on a mac and a poor mouse and it ran perfectly. This game may not look like it but if you put the time and effort into it, it will blow your mind. If you can get over mediocre graphics and sorta outdated combat then trust me you'll love this. Anyone who appreciates a good MMO will absolutely LOVE this game!

reviewText:
Lord of the Rings Online.. Is it good or bad? I would have to say this is a generally good game. This game is very much your typical mmorpg game. The controls are very simple and easily understood. You spend most of your time in third person observing your character, combat involves locking onto a target, then clicking (or using a hotkey) to trigger the different attacks that are displayed on your action bar. Area attacks do exist, and generally the physics play out reasonably well.

The World: The world is big. There is plenty of places to explore, and the graphical level is pleasing to look at. While it will not match up in freedom of movement, or detail to Skyrim, it is definitely a fun place to view and explore. At first the world will seem pretty small, it is only as you go along that the distances between locations grow to the point where it is unpleasant to travel there by foot. They did, however, do a good job of matching up when distances get long, with when you your character can get a horse. In summary: medium-big world that is aesthetically very pleasing to look at.

Questing: The questing system is very closed. You progress through them, some of them are voiced, most only have one or two lines of voiced dialogue the rest you have to read on your own, you rarely have any options. They do not support the player choosing to be evil or good, or making choices that will have impacts upon how the quest will progress. Despite the limited nature of it, they did a fairly good job of making stories that are interesting, and that fit with the lore of Middle Earth. Summary: lack of player options, but decently entertaining anyhow.

Characters: Character setup is highly limited. You can choose from four races (Dwarf, Elf, Hobbit Man). Then you have a group of Classes;[some titles may be wrong] Guardian, Champion, Burglar, Warden, Rune-Keeper, Hunter, Captain and Lore Master. The races share the classes, with a few classes being disabled for each race (for example no Dwarf Burglars, or Human Rune Keepers. Each class also has three 'paths' that they can follow, those will effect what kinds of weapons they will be good at, and how well your character is at solo play. In general, there is almost no cross-over between classes, and no way to change once you make your character, so research well before you make a choice.

Crafting: There is almost nothing to talk about here. You choose a craft that contains three skills. Some skills let you gather, others let you craft. No single craft you can choose is completely self-reliant, so you will need the help of friends or the general world market to level up all of your skills. Crafted weapons are, however, well worth the effort of getting. They are on average far better than what you can find through loot for your level.

General play: While this game is termed a role-playing game"
date: there is very little actual role-playing to be found on it. The role-playing servers rarely have players who actually actively try to take on their character's roles. There are some good communities that you can join in with
recommended: but if you are on your own do not expect players to be particularly sociable or in character. Outside of role-playing the community is very open and helpful. Questions are typically answered quickly and nicely
hoursPlayed: and there are almost always players around who are willing to help you out. There are also plenty of player friendly guilds/factions out there to join if you enjoy that kind of play.\n\ntl;dr
voteText: generic mmorpg

reviewText:
I've been playing this game for quite a while, Shadows of Angmar days in 2008.
I have stopped with this game quite a few times. Yet I still comeback and play it.
It's like the classic MMO but with the LOTR lore, sounds awesome.
The game plays great, even though they use target-tabbin, I have yet to see such fluid combat in other MMO.
It feels great. You really feel like you're hitting or being hit. This is one of the reasons I keep coming back.
The PVP can be freaking awesome and incredibly tedious.
Questing can actually be fun, but to get from 1 to 100 should take so long that I'd doubt it feels fun after a while.
PVE used to be really great, but the old content is abandoned and they haven't released a new raid in a while now.
The community is one of the best assets of the game, I have made quite a few friends for life over here.
Finally, with all the great things I had to say, and that keep me coming back, I must say:

This is Free-To-Play until some point. You can always play it, but you'll eventually need to take some money off your pocket to unlock later content. The currency you buy, Turbine Points, can be gathered through gameplay, but to get enough would take over a thousand hours.

P.S.: This isn't a P2W game. They surely sell a lot of convenience, and people who pay can really get to that point with less effort, but they don't really sell advantage (anymore).

reviewText:
This is my favourite MMO of all time. It follows the story of Tolkien's books from the Lord of the Rings. You can explore Middle Earth by your own, or you can follow the epic story line, which brings you to all the regions. The quests are good, there are a lot of different quest types, and when you're lucky, you can join a festival as well.

The things I like about the game is the beautiful scenery, the storyline, cosmetics(!), and the player community is one of the best I know. There are 4 player races, all with their own backgroundstory. The classes are also fun to play (I tried them all). Another good thing is that it is normally F2P, so you can try it out as long as you like. You don't have to pay a monthly fee, unless you want some extras.

The only downside is, that the expansions and the extras can be expensive. But when you play is often, it is totally worth the money.

My rating for the game: 7,5/10

reviewText:
To properly appreciate this game, you need to invest a fair amount of time into. I would say the game itself is a fairly standard RPG, perhaps above average for a free to play and it doesn't bog you down in restricted VIP only areas. However, a big selling point for me was the fact it was LOTR and I got to explore all the places I wanted to visit from the films. This was FRIGGIN AWESOME. I admit, I spent the majority of this game playing with friends, so I cannot vouch for the solo experience but questing together was the most fun I had on an MMORPG.


Throughout the game, you may be able to save up enough currency to never need to invest actual money into it, however I bought the mithril starter pack which gave me enough points to progress as far as I wanted. The first purchase you need to save for is buying a horse to actually be able to get around. This is relatively painless and involves completing a fair few early tasks to get the points. Apart from that advice, take your sword, your bow and your axe and go out and explore the world of MiddleEarth!

reviewText: I recommend the game, but I would much rather prefer you to pay $30.00 for a two-month Battle.net account and pay another $30.00 for World of Warcraft online or at Walmart which is much better. I think this game is not near as inteesting and I don't think there are many fun quests. I still haven't figured out how to get trained in mining. I saw the trainer on my mini-map, but I never found him. It's like he just disappeared. I still think it's a nice game for someone who is new to MMORPG games, and when you're experienced, get World of Warcraft. I do like the combat system, though. I just wish that the creators would add hundreds of more enemies and enemy types. And also make it to where it doesn't take me half an hour to find a mining trainer. I still like it, though. Even if this review sounds like I completely hate it. It's a free MMORPG, and that's what made me want to get the game. Maybe it's because none of my characters are high leveled, and that's why I don't get many fighting quests. Good game, though. Thank you for whoever read this review. Have a good day!

reviewText: This was one of my first MMOs and I am so happy it was. The combat and graphics may seem a little outdated but it is still fun beyond belief. It's not easy but it's not too challenging, it's super fun to play with your friends, the map is GIANT and there's so much to see and do. Within my first few days of playing I was invited to a guild by very nice players who taught me everything and showed me how to play, I progressed slowly until I was a total bad ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, I spent hours looking for the correct ores to make the best weapons and armor possible. The gameplay is perfect. You start out by fighting wolves with a weak short sword and leather armor and a few days later you'll be taking on orcs and giants with your friends and dual wielding swords that took hours to make and heavy steel armor. THe progression is quite slow which personally I love. But that may bother some people. You can do epic boss fights and raids to earn special money that you can spend at camps to get weapons and armor that look like they were crafted by the gods. This game is also truly free to play. If you want to spend real money on special coins go ahead but it's definitely not forced upon you. You can do everything without spending a dime. I played this game all spring break with my friend. It doesn't matter if you have an old mac and a poor mouse. I spent the majority of this game on a mac and a poor mouse and it ran perfectly. This game may not look like it but if you put the time and effort into it, it will blow your mind. If you can get over mediocre graphics and sorta outdated combat then trust me you'll love this. Anyone who appreciates a good MMO will absolutely LOVE this game!

reviewText:
I've  been a fan of Lord of the Rings and the Hobbit since I read the books way back when. The movies where amazing. So when my brother introduced me and got me into the game ( A change of pace from my usual Chaos Space Marines)  but the opportunity to play a fantasy realm in witch we both were avid fans about, I took the chance.  Both of us being our favorite hero as Gimli, son of Gloin, we took to the character creation with an idea of mind. ( I'm also a dwarf slayer fan from the Gotrek and Felix novels.) To be long bearded, axe toting dwarves. And as it was , we could! Other than dwarves you can play as other races of the Free Peoples of Middle Earth...men, hobbits and elfs. Also like other rpg's you can choose from various classes. Champion, Guardian, Hunter, Burgler and Loremaster. Each class and race brings to the game a specific play style along with culture and language and skills and story line. Dwarves for example, get and axe damage bonus and a stamina regenerative bonus for being a harty people.  So choosing and making you're character does change you're online game experience.

The game itself is so fully in depth and full of fantasy lore that its hard not to be overwhelmed and lost in it. Even if your just a fan of the books, or just the movies or just like rpg's. You'll find yourself reading the quests and missions, enjoying the simple basic rpg mechanics( Legendary weapons is A LOT of fun) and instances its hard not to be captured by Tolkiens world. Its all there, down to the movies soundtrack to add to you actually want the music up and loud when you‚Äôre slaying goblins in the Misty Mountains. In game you play as a hero of the Free Peoples defeating every orc and goblins in league with evil, from Erin Luin to Moria (my favorite) to Gondor.

Community wise it has to be the most friendly based I have ever played with. There is always a fellowship, kinship out there to help with a quest or instance or get items or even craft them for you free of charge. Honestly it has a great atmosphere with a '' Were in this together'' and ''All for one and one for all '' attitude. A great game if you like joining with others and having fun rpg dungeon crawl wise.

As a free to play game technically, there is a pay to play feature. With real money you can buy traits, skills, steeds, quests and maps that can easily create a large hole in your pocket. But if you choose to pay you definitely wont be found wanting. Even as a free to play game there is plenty of content and game play that you won‚Äôt be crying exactly that you didn't get the full experience. but there is so much more, if  you are willing to pay for it. It doesn‚Äôt make your character so much better than others or game changing where you become a God amongst men, but it definitely can change your experience. To make your steed go 250% faster or to play that one instance where you defeat the orc armies of the Iron crown. It‚Äôs up to you. As a free to play player myself sometimes you do wish you could do a certain quest or skirmish and there is a way. In game, for completing quests and deeds you can earn Turbine points which can pay for real money perks! It's a nice way to get some of those pay to play perks for us that have empty wallets.

reviewText: I've been playing this game since the summer of 2012 (though only just recently through Steam), and it is easily one of the best games I've ever played, and most certainly one of my favorites. The world is so massive and fun to explore, all the quests are enjoyable and I actually want to do all the side quests, and the story quests are really engaging. At many points I find myself wanting to know what happens next. The lore of Middle-earth is very well represented, and the game feels very true to the source material, even though it does take liberties, as one would expect. The community is a good one, and you can almost always find somebody in-game to help you out. Even when you can't, for the fellowship quests you just have to gain a few more levels and it's definitely within reach. Of the nine classes I've played (all but the Lore-master) they're all unique and fun to play. The Hunter in particular is a good beginning class, since it has a wide range of ranged and melee skills, and the quick travel skills are lifesavers. I'm only at level 70 on my main character, and that's exactly the sort of pace this game requires: nice and easy. It's a game that really draws you in, and even when I'm not actually doing a quest or deed or other objective, I still love just going around and exploring the Middle-earth Turbine has created for their game. I cannot stress the beauty of the game enough. Each and every area is unique and beautiful. From the rural hills of The Shire, to the torch lit caverns of Moria, each new vista amazes. I can't wait to see where my adventures will take me next!\nOverall, not only is this a great MMO, it's just a great all-around game, and I would highly recommend it to anybody interested in the world of Middle-earth.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: I used to love this game.  Then, after they released the update for Helm's Deep, they abandoned the whole skill tree, and re-did everything.  I felt overwhelmed...I had carefully planned my character's development over LITERALLY THOUSANDS of hours of gameplay.  Yes, I know that there's something wrong with that.  In my defense, between bouts of grinding, there was something terribly soothing about standing above the valley of Rivendell.  But how could I start over?  Without the skills and perks configured, MOBs of my own level would likely waste me.  Yet if I mis-spent them, I'd be stuck with a fouled-up configuration, unless I paid to re-spec.  So it sits in the queue, unused.  I thought Minas Tirith was available now...I had so longed to make my way to the White City.  But even that appears to dangle out of reach.  (thanks Dr. Wumbo for correction)  Perhaps someday I shall yet return...some day...ah.\n\nIf you enjoyed the books, and have a LOT of extra time on your hands, and sometimes find yourself wishing to spend some time in Tolkien's world, you could hardly do worse than to spend some time with this game.  I bought it long before it was free-to-play, and it was worth it.  (Shoot, I'd have bought the lifetime sub back when it was available if I had known how much I'd like it.)  And if you're starting now, you needn't face my conundrum...unless Turbine does it AGAIN, in which case it may be time to craft a new legendary weapon.

reviewText:
As you can see i have alot of houres on record.

This game is free to play and you can run around the entire world but to be able to do quests you will need to buy them. you buy them with turbine points. these points are also gained by completing deeds. So in fact if you want you could play this game completely for free but it just takes longer.

I personaly realy like the game because of the realy big world and the manny possibilities you have withing the game.
first off when starting you have 5 differend races to choose of and within those races manny differend classes (some don't work with some races). a few you have to buy with TP.
there are 4 differend starting stories that help you to get to know the game.
one of the big things on the side is crafting. you can make annything. in the differend areas are differend recourses.

the grafics are not top notch but for such a huge game it is fantastic and if you have all the grafic setings maxed out you can find some realy nice vieuws.
The social aspect of the game is realy important for manny quests are hard to impossible to complete on your own.
thanks to the fellowships this can be done. And a mayor part of the time you will find yourself playing in a kinship. I met some amazing people from all over the world, some youngh some old (ranging 15-65) but all amazing in their own way.
the game does allow in game voice chat but the quality isn't so superb.

i personly love this game, the most time i ever put into one game. almost at 2000 houres.

reviewText:
I've played this game for ages (since 2009). Thousands of hours more than Steam will show. It has been a long running favorite with huge amounts of space to explore and a skirmish system that other MMOs need to pay attention to.

The downside is the game is starting to show its age a bit more than WoW does. The art in the game manages to land square in the uncanny valley and the player animation is sloppy. Anyone with a speed buff comically trots in place when starting or stopping. No ability to unsheath weapons, and everyone in your party will be synchronized when entering or exting combat. These things are minor, but jarring. Hunter's port system has become a chore, and travel from point to point to point is now confusing and tedious. Travel needs to be revamped to just a drop down of where you want to go at this point. Also, a lot of this game is simply NIH going extra lengths to not be WoW even when WoW-like was the right thing to do.

The upside is the game continuously expands and improves. New gameplay mechanics, often new innovations, are introduced with each year. The lore is immersive (as it should be), and elaboration happens with consent and approval from the Tolkien estate. The cosmetic outfit system is an example of a place where WoW (and every other MMO) specifically needs to take notice. Content is often truely difficult rather than outright unfair, even when playing retro-content several levels under you.

Warsteeds were a fizzle addition to the game, largely because they amplified the slop in the controls by an intentionally sloppy and unweidly system. PvMP (because WoW calls it PvP) is amazing, but often unbalanced as stats start in favor of monsters and end in favor of Hobbits by the end of an xpac cycle. Legendary weapons are not cosmetically customizable and obsoleted every xpac. This flys in the face of the intent of the original intent of the system, and is a very tedious grind. The legendary system is also confusing and dependant on huge amounts of randomness. Keep these as your forwarning as they will be the biggest sore points.

Despite the complaints here, I still love this game. I still recommend this game. I hope that they will approach fixing the sloppy controls and simplify the legendary system as these are the only things causing me to drift towards other games.

reviewText: While it says I have 7 minutes on Steam, I played at least 500 hours of this game before it was here. The reason that I have not restarted playing it is because seeing the game again was to much nostalgia for me to handle.\n\nLord of the Rings Online is probably one of the best RPGs out there, even though it doesn't have a massive playerbase like some other ones. The community is very friendly, and this is especially important when you have the ability to create and join Fellowships and Kinships. The combat is simple enough to understand easily, yet advanced enough to not get boring after playing for as long as I have. The landscape of the many lands you can visit is very well made, with amazing mountains, valleys, and of course, plenty of enemy buildings to raid. The enemies are fun to fight, especially if you find a randomly generated boss wandering the wilderness. This game also has great economy, with ways to earn large volumes of money at low and high level areas. I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone looking for a good RPG -- I hope you will enjoy it as much as I did.

reviewText: Certainly one of the best MMORPG games out there. This MMO is directly linked with the books and only a few popular movie scenes are seen in the game. Beautiful and breath-taking views, tearrain, story, quests, gameplay and more. It's certainly a game which they spent a lot of time making. Playing this game is a lot of fun and very addicting. Many people play this game despite the fact that Steam is just rerouting players to the official LotRO launcher. However, I enjoy this game and I've been playing it for over three years now. Multiple toons, high levels, gone through all instances/raids/big battles, et cetera. The game will never end, and your toon will never be finished. It will always be better, though. This game is a bunch of fun to play with friends as well, so I highly recommend you invite some friends to join you up.

reviewText: I like this franchise a lot, and I like this game too. It does open a lot if you pay to play mind you! I find that with this game once you get to Mines Of Moria thing's start to get a lot more interesting, for instance to enter the mines, they give you a Legendary weapon. Also, the areas in the expansion packs look very pretty, the Vanilla game does too, but the expansions even more so. I think the zones are very big as well, sometimes too big, but then again they are pretty acurate to the books. I think my favorate questing area has to be the Hobbit area as that place is the most cheerful and colourful too. For anyone thinking of playing this game, do yourself a favor and get a Subscription, even if it's only for one month, as it opens up four bags, and removes the gold cap, and gives you 500 Turbine Points to do as you please with, plus any character you make in that month will be able to learn to do their riding traits for free which will stay with that character even when you un-subscribe.\n\nOverall, if you read the books and liked them, you will propably love this game. If you only watched the movies, then this game may still appeal to you, but one thing to note this game is based on the books not the movies. A good effort by Turbine in my opinion and nice to see they didn't shut it down!

reviewText:
Ahhh,LOTRo where to begin.This game is honestly the best classic tab targeting MMO i have ever played.Before i tell why i think so i will first tell you the cons of this game as to get them out of the way.

1.Its a bit old so the graphics are not as good as modern games,still pleasent graphics(its not virtua fighter)just not as nice
as shiny new games

2.Its new content is made under a differant company then old LOTRO so it feels a bit differant,not bad just differant.

3.Long travel times between destinations.This is commonplace in MMOs but LOTRO is big and fast travel is limited so yeah,lots of running around.This is easily mitigated by LOTROs excellent vistas and the steam overview if you wanna browse the store or something while traveling,or just talk in chat.

PROS!!!

1.Firstly and most important is that LOTROs community is by far the best in any game.This fact is so true as to almost be undebatable.Every person i have ever met in this game was great.

2.This is lord of the rings,so you instantly have the greatest fantasy world and lore ever created to explore and adventure in.

3.Varied classes.You start with some good class staples like Guardian and Hunter,but some really special ones are included like warden(a combo based tank in a tab targeting game?Its crazy fun for more skill based play.Runekeeper(super adaptible healer/dps)and countless other cool stuff about the other classes.

4.The world building is close to perfect for a classic (but fresh) take on the lord of the rings.

In conclusion i love this this game and while you may not,you have to try it,at least two very differant classes to lvl 30,and make friends!these people are great they make f2ps and newbies right at home.GO PLAY IT!

reviewText: Overall I love this game and would recommend it to anyone. What I like about this game is that there are a lot of things to do from customizing your character, weapons, clothing, housing all of it. There are lots of quest too some some of which are repeatable. You even get to pick a trade like woodworking or being a scholar just to name a few. You can join a kinship or start one of your own and help eachother out. You also get to interact with the original characters from Middle Earth like Gandalf, Aragorn, Legolas, Frodo, and so many others. The one thing I think is a drawback is that you have to spend money to unlock most reigons in order to be able to do quest in them and there are some other items such as mounts and clothing that you need to buy with money as well. And there is a gold cap so you have to pay to expand that as well. So unless you have a job, or some deep pockets you can dig into and if you're not a giant passionionate fan for Lord of the Rings then this game is mostlikey not for you. But if the above is not an issue for you then I would totally say this is a great game for you. :)

reviewText:
One of the few MMO titles I've played for more than six months. If you are a fan of Tolkien's universe, LotRO is a wonderful adaption of it. Rather than having you be a part of the fellowship, or actively assisting the ringbearer at all times, Turbine has devised a story that follows the events of the book by foiling the plans of Sauron, Sarumon and others who do not have the interest of the free peoples of Middle-earth in mind.

Start in Ered Luin (home of the Elves and Dwarves), The Bree-lands (home of the race of Man) or The Shire (home of the Hobbits), and make your way through one of the largest game worlds created. Travel through Evendim (it's landmark being Annuminas and Lake Evendim itself), Forochel (home of the Lossoth, a tribe living on the frigid tundra), The North Downs (where the Rangers have made base to keep guard over The Shire), The Lone Lands (it's landmark being Weathertop), The Trollshaws (it's landmark being Imladris, the city of Elves), The Misty Mountains (it's landmark being Goblin-town), Eregion (which leads you to the black pool and gates of Moria), down into the Enedwaith and on into Dunland (it's landmark being the Tower of Orthanc).

Should you journey east from Eregion, you then enter the vastness of Moria on into Lothlorien, where you can journey further east into Mirkwood or south down the Great River to the Wildermores and Eastern Rohan, a massive region comprised of four areas; The Wold, The Entwash Vale, The Norcrofts and The Sutcrofts. From there, you will travel into Western Rohan, on to Edoras and on to Helm's Deep.

LotRO is also the epitome of Free To Play. While a player does not have immediate access to everything the game has to offer, one can purchase nearly everything with Turbine Points, a currency you can purchase with  real cash or earn by playing the game and completing deeds. If you're not willing to spend money, you can spend time to get the newest stuff, from cosmetics to mounts to expansion packs.

Storywise, as of this writing, LotRO has just reached The Battle of Helm's Deep with it's new expansion (released Nov. 20, 2013), aptly titled Helm's Deep"."

reviewText:
So, I've played through the intro of this game and done a bit of free roaming with my friend, so I thought I'd give some first impressions. (The Quest Log section may be updated, so you may want to check back at some point if you're interested, which I expect you aren't).

PLOT:

Judging by the intro and the dream sequence at level 5, your character (my first one being the Hobbit Burgular, Mimbulius) is the chosen one (or something like that) whose destiny is tied to the fate of Middle-Earth! The story is set out in quests that vary depending on which character you are (my friend was a dwarf and met Gandalf and Thorin and all the other dwarves from The Hobbit while I was just helping out around this little village that got attacked for five minutes).

GAMEPLAY:

Open World, quest-based gameplay. It is very much like World of Warcraft, but it's still a good MMO.

QUEST LOG:

Day 1: My friend and I set out from Erebor on the free horses they give you for 24 hours after completing the intro, and we decided that we were going to go from Erebor to Mordor, stopping at certain locations to look around. We rode to Hobbiton, where we found Bag End and looked around, then we headed off into the Bree-Lands to find The Inn of the Prancing Pony. My friend thought he could take on a bear, and it chased us all the way into Bree. At the Pony, I got my haircut and got drunk, while my friend sold all his junk items to Barliman Butterbur. We then set off for Weathertop, as my friend did not want to stay the night in Bree as to be safe. Weathertop is in the Lone Lands, what we now know to be as quite a dangerous place for two Level Sixes to be riding through at night. My friend was lucky and actually managed to make it onto the ruins, but I, however, was attacked by some freaking ravens! Meanwhile, my friend wasn't having the best time up on the hill, and he managed to use some magical item or something to teleport back to Erebor. It was just me now, so I rode on, past Weathertop, to try and go through the Trollshaws to Rivendell...I was killed two minutes later, and used my instant respawn, only to be killed again about twenty seconds after. I then respawned at a safe place (the entrance to the Lone Lands) as day began. My ride through the Lone Lands was fine, and nothing attacked me at all. If only my friend had actually listened when I suggested waiting in Bree until morning. I entered the Trollshaws, and the game warned me that this area was Level 30, but I was determined. I rode through the Trollshaws, with monsters chasing me. I reached the river that seperates the Trollshaws from Rivendell, and rode on. I could not see a path to Rivendell, so I rode up a hill to get a better view. At this point, I stopped, and, as I checked the map, the monsters caught up with me and attacked me. I moved away from the monsters, and they chased me. I moved back again, forgetting a crucial detail - I was on the edge of a hill. I fell 200ft, still riding my horse, and died as my body smashed into the same river I had believed to be the end of my worries. I had to use a 'Safe Respawn' that took me to the middle of a place called Archet, on the borders of Bree. I left to go and play Town of Salem instead.

reviewText: Overall I love this game and would recommend it to anyone. What I like about this game is that there are a lot of things to do from customizing your character, weapons, clothing, housing all of it. There are lots of quest too some some of which are repeatable. You even get to pick a trade like woodworking or being a scholar just to name a few. You can join a kinship or start one of your own and help eachother out. You also get to interact with the original characters from Middle Earth like Gandalf, Aragorn, Legolas, Frodo, and so many others. The one thing I think is a drawback is that you have to spend money to unlock most reigons in order to be able to do quest in them and there are some other items such as mounts and clothing that you need to buy with money as well. And there is a gold cap so you have to pay to expand that as well. So unless you have a job, or some deep pockets you can dig into and if you're not a giant passionionate fan for Lord of the Rings then this game is mostlikey not for you. But if the above is not an issue for you then I would totally say this is a great game for you. :)

reviewText:
So, I've played through the intro of this game and done a bit of free roaming with my friend, so I thought I'd give some first impressions. (The Quest Log section may be updated, so you may want to check back at some point if you're interested, which I expect you aren't).

PLOT:

Judging by the intro and the dream sequence at level 5, your character (my first one being the Hobbit Burgular, Mimbulius) is the chosen one (or something like that) whose destiny is tied to the fate of Middle-Earth! The story is set out in quests that vary depending on which character you are (my friend was a dwarf and met Gandalf and Thorin and all the other dwarves from The Hobbit while I was just helping out around this little village that got attacked for five minutes).

GAMEPLAY:

Open World, quest-based gameplay. It is very much like World of Warcraft, but it's still a good MMO.

QUEST LOG:

Day 1: My friend and I set out from Erebor on the free horses they give you for 24 hours after completing the intro, and we decided that we were going to go from Erebor to Mordor, stopping at certain locations to look around. We rode to Hobbiton, where we found Bag End and looked around, then we headed off into the Bree-Lands to find The Inn of the Prancing Pony. My friend thought he could take on a bear, and it chased us all the way into Bree. At the Pony, I got my haircut and got drunk, while my friend sold all his junk items to Barliman Butterbur. We then set off for Weathertop, as my friend did not want to stay the night in Bree as to be safe. Weathertop is in the Lone Lands, what we now know to be as quite a dangerous place for two Level Sixes to be riding through at night. My friend was lucky and actually managed to make it onto the ruins, but I, however, was attacked by some freaking ravens! Meanwhile, my friend wasn't having the best time up on the hill, and he managed to use some magical item or something to teleport back to Erebor. It was just me now, so I rode on, past Weathertop, to try and go through the Trollshaws to Rivendell...I was killed two minutes later, and used my instant respawn, only to be killed again about twenty seconds after. I then respawned at a safe place (the entrance to the Lone Lands) as day began. My ride through the Lone Lands was fine, and nothing attacked me at all. If only my friend had actually listened when I suggested waiting in Bree until morning. I entered the Trollshaws, and the game warned me that this area was Level 30, but I was determined. I rode through the Trollshaws, with monsters chasing me. I reached the river that seperates the Trollshaws from Rivendell, and rode on. I could not see a path to Rivendell, so I rode up a hill to get a better view. At this point, I stopped, and, as I checked the map, the monsters caught up with me and attacked me. I moved away from the monsters, and they chased me. I moved back again, forgetting a crucial detail - I was on the edge of a hill. I fell 200ft, still riding my horse, and died as my body smashed into the same river I had believed to be the end of my worries. I had to use a 'Safe Respawn' that took me to the middle of a place called Archet, on the borders of Bree. I left to go and play Town of Salem instead.

reviewText: I like this franchise a lot, and I like this game too. It does open a lot if you pay to play mind you! I find that with this game once you get to Mines Of Moria thing's start to get a lot more interesting, for instance to enter the mines, they give you a Legendary weapon. Also, the areas in the expansion packs look very pretty, the Vanilla game does too, but the expansions even more so. I think the zones are very big as well, sometimes too big, but then again they are pretty acurate to the books. I think my favorate questing area has to be the Hobbit area as that place is the most cheerful and colourful too. For anyone thinking of playing this game, do yourself a favor and get a Subscription, even if it's only for one month, as it opens up four bags, and removes the gold cap, and gives you 500 Turbine Points to do as you please with, plus any character you make in that month will be able to learn to do their riding traits for free which will stay with that character even when you un-subscribe.\n\nOverall, if you read the books and liked them, you will propably love this game. If you only watched the movies, then this game may still appeal to you, but one thing to note this game is based on the books not the movies. A good effort by Turbine in my opinion and nice to see they didn't shut it down!

reviewText:
One of the few MMO titles I've played for more than six months. If you are a fan of Tolkien's universe, LotRO is a wonderful adaption of it. Rather than having you be a part of the fellowship, or actively assisting the ringbearer at all times, Turbine has devised a story that follows the events of the book by foiling the plans of Sauron, Sarumon and others who do not have the interest of the free peoples of Middle-earth in mind.

Start in Ered Luin (home of the Elves and Dwarves), The Bree-lands (home of the race of Man) or The Shire (home of the Hobbits), and make your way through one of the largest game worlds created. Travel through Evendim (it's landmark being Annuminas and Lake Evendim itself), Forochel (home of the Lossoth, a tribe living on the frigid tundra), The North Downs (where the Rangers have made base to keep guard over The Shire), The Lone Lands (it's landmark being Weathertop), The Trollshaws (it's landmark being Imladris, the city of Elves), The Misty Mountains (it's landmark being Goblin-town), Eregion (which leads you to the black pool and gates of Moria), down into the Enedwaith and on into Dunland (it's landmark being the Tower of Orthanc).

Should you journey east from Eregion, you then enter the vastness of Moria on into Lothlorien, where you can journey further east into Mirkwood or south down the Great River to the Wildermores and Eastern Rohan, a massive region comprised of four areas; The Wold, The Entwash Vale, The Norcrofts and The Sutcrofts. From there, you will travel into Western Rohan, on to Edoras and on to Helm's Deep.

LotRO is also the epitome of Free To Play. While a player does not have immediate access to everything the game has to offer, one can purchase nearly everything with Turbine Points, a currency you can purchase with  real cash or earn by playing the game and completing deeds. If you're not willing to spend money, you can spend time to get the newest stuff, from cosmetics to mounts to expansion packs.

Storywise, as of this writing, LotRO has just reached The Battle of Helm's Deep with it's new expansion (released Nov. 20, 2013), aptly titled Helm's Deep"."

reviewText:
So, I've been playing this game off and on for the last four and a half years, so I would say I've seen enough of it to write an hoenst review. What I love most about the game are the story and the immersion you feel when you're playing. You really feel like you're a part of the Middle Earth World, which to me means a lot (I'm obssessed with Lord of the Rings). The regions are varied enough that you feel like every place is different. Also, each class has its own unique characteristics that set it apart from the other classes; most people have multiple characters on multiple servors because they want to capitalize on all the different class options and play styles.

The main problems I have with LOTRO are that the combat is getting clunky, certain classes are way overpowered compared to others, and the questing in certain regions is getting a bit monotonous. The combat is generally the same the whole game, so it's important that you pick the class that goes with what you want in the game. It can just be very repetitive at times. Likewise, certain classes are way stronger than other classes. My hunter is so frail at level 89 compared to most other classes. So frail that it becomes difficult to get through basic solo quests. Finally, the quest are around the same thing over and over again. I know there can only be a finite number of quest ideas, but I would appreciate more diversity in questing.

Overall, I find myself coming back to this game every couple of months, getting bored, and then coming back again in a cycle. I've done this for four years now, and I expect to d othe same for at least a couple more years. 8.5/10

reviewText:
Grindy and repetitive, yet oddly satisfying.

Much of the features are locked behind store upgrades. Fortunantly, you can earn currency for the store through certain accomplishments inside the game. This secondary means of gaining store currency is an outstanding feature that is rather elegant compared to other models seen in other free to play titles.

To unlock everything you must either grind out ingame (recommended) or purchase the currency, the game actually providing a choice for a completely free to play experience.

Do note that this game has a habit of deleting characters of extremely low activity, so don't expect a character to last longer than 2 months without some sort of activity.

reviewText:
Great MMO! If you enjoyed anything The Lord of the Rings is, you should play this game. It has its flaws, like any game, but overall a great experience!!

Good things:
- Immense world
- Fine graphics for a MMO
- Less pay2play than most free2play MMO's around
- Very great community
- Legendary Weapons (for me they are the most great expression of gear in a MMO)

Bad things:
- PvP system is kind of a joke... A good one for me personally. But undeniable a bit of a joke.
- Not as populated as back in the days, if you play this kind of games with people there are 2 main servers you can join on LotRO for alot of action... (Brandywine for the US & Snowbourn for the EU) The rest are pretty near empty, even compared to other games' low populated" servers.

Overall score I would say a 9/10
date: but this game has alot of emotional worth to me. Most people would rate lower."

reviewText:
I started playing Lotro at launch and then stopped playing for many years. I have recently come back (after being inspired by the Hobbit movies!) and I'm really enjoying it.

The free to play model is very generous here; there is an absolute ton of content to play for free including the entire epic quest which is really good. Plus just by playing normally you earn Turbine points which can be used to unlock niceties such as the ability to ride a horse and so on.

It's a very content rich game, with great story amd there's also a lot of fun stuff to do with all the festival. The community is one of the nicest ones in the MMO space and if you are into RP then this is very well catered for on some of the RP servers.

reviewText:
Great MMO! If you enjoyed anything The Lord of the Rings is, you should play this game. It has its flaws, like any game, but overall a great experience!!

Good things:
- Immense world
- Fine graphics for a MMO
- Less pay2play than most free2play MMO's around
- Very great community
- Legendary Weapons (for me they are the most great expression of gear in a MMO)

Bad things:
- PvP system is kind of a joke... A good one for me personally. But undeniable a bit of a joke.
- Not as populated as back in the days, if you play this kind of games with people there are 2 main servers you can join on LotRO for alot of action... (Brandywine for the US & Snowbourn for the EU) The rest are pretty near empty, even compared to other games' low populated" servers.

Overall score I would say a 9/10
date: but this game has alot of emotional worth to me. Most people would rate lower."

reviewText: Lord of the rings online is a game you want to play if you are a fan of Tolkien's books or just a mmorpg player. WoW players out there might be interested in this game. In my opinion, this game brings Tolkien's books to life. You can actually travel around Middle-earth and fight different creatures, like orcs, wargs, Uruk-hais and a lot more. You can also invite people to form a fellowship and then do skirmishes together, which can be epic! This game is playable without paying money, as you can complete deeds to earn turbine points to purchase things in the lotro store, like expansions etc. Graphics are not the best, but the landscapes are still very beautiful, say Evendim :) I played like a month ago and absolutely fell in love with it, its free, so why not try it? :)

reviewText: As a huge fan of LOTR and JRRT's world in general, I was looking forward to playing this game as soon as it was announced. Unfortunately, I just couldn't get it installed for a very, very long time until Steam came over to Russia. Now I had my chance to play and form my opinion.\nI really liked the graphics - much better than I expected. The mapping of the world is nicely done, lots of great and beautiful locations, and an interesting storyline too. At first, that is. Unfortunately, it all gets rather dull as you have to perform tons of similar quests to get that XP and get stuff without paying money for it. reviewText:
I played this game on and off for about 3-4 years roughly. But I don't play this game vary often. It is a good standard MMO based on J.R.R. Tolkien's fantasy world that brings old Celtic and Norse Mythology into today's lores. The game is much bigger since I started playing it sometimes, and there can be much to do in this game. Play the main story, practice your toon or character's crafting skill, go fishing, chat with other players in the game about whatever if they're willing and in the mood, or just roam around this mini version of Middle Earth like a Hobbit without a hill or a Dwarf without a Mountain.

To put the rest in short, the community is good depending on server, the gameplay is good, and it does have a serious pvp community even though this has lost some participation compared to a few years ago. The only drawback to this game is the ftp option feels more like a free sample than free to play. It's allot like Star Wars the Old Republic with micro buying. So its still technically pay to play like WoW, but one can still have fun with the ftp option. It's just not as generous as Star Trek Online or Rift.

So yes I would recommend this game to nearly anyone.
